ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

TRIPARTITE CONSULTATIVE
COMMITTEE
(Terms of Reference)


    1. Mr Lee Choon Eng asked the Minister for Labour and Welfare what are the terms of reference of the Tripartite Consultative Committee set up for the three Services Unions; whether any, and how many, meetings have been held; and what has been the outcome of such meetings.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Tripartite Consultative Committee, as its name suggests, was merely to be a forum for the exchange of views on matters of common interest to the Service Departments, the Services Unions

Column: 786

and the Government, the three parties therein represented. In particular, the subjects of transferability of pension rights and of ascertaining whether public bodies could find jobs for employees about to become redundant in Service employment. It therefore has no specific terms of reference beyond these, and subjects are only brought up for discussion if agreed by all three parties.

    It was also agreed that the Committee should not in any way supersede joint consultative machinery which already exists in the various Service Departments, by which conditions of service and related matters are already negotiable, nor was it intended that the Committee should be a higher tribunal than the bodies already constituted in the Service Departments for negotiating conditions of service, etc. Nevertheless, Sir, through such joint consultations held at 15 meetings up to the end of September, 1958, the following matters had been resolved satisfactorily:

    (a) Recruitment in the Singapore Local Forces Establishment for clerks, storekeepers, etc, should, as far as possible, be made from the ranks of redundant employees who possess the requisite qualifications and experience.

    (b) Fair opportunity should be given to redundant civilian employees of the Service Departments who register themselves in the Government Employment Exchange for whatever jobs are vacant.

    (c) Information was supplied by the Labour Department on the types and rates of severance pay to enable the Services Unions to negotiate their own claims for severance pay for redundant civilian employees to be payable by the Service Departments.

    (d) Waiver of hospitalisation deposits had already been agreed in principle by the Ministry of Health through discussions in the Tripartite Consultative Committee which has now finalised with that Ministry the form of guarantee and the scheme will be implemented on the 1st of November, 1958.

    (e) Various avenues of alternative employment for redundant employees were explored from time to time with very little result, as there are few employment opportunities available.

BUKIT PANJANG
(Agricultural Roads)
(Statement)


    2. Mr Goh Tong Liang asked the Minister for Local Government, Lands and Housing if he will make a statement regarding the construction programme for agricultural roads in the Bukit Panjang electoral division.

    Dato Abdul Hamid Bin Haji Jumat: Mr Speaker, Sir, for the construction and improvement of agricultural roads in the Bukit Panjang electoral division of the Legislative Assembly, the Rural Board's normal programme for 1958 would permit the making up of roads totalling approximately 15 miles in length at a total cost of $79,000. To date work has been commenced and is expected to be completed by the end of this year on three roads totalling a distance of 4 miles approximately, while work on the remaining roads, some 12 miles long, is being planned and will be put in hand later.

    Apart from this, Sir, Government, bearing in mind the necessity for accelerating the improvement of rural areas, has directed the carrying out simultaneously of a further programme of road construction and improvement. Out of the provision of $730,000 which was voted in the Assembly this year, Government will be spending $113,000 on the construction of 21 miles of road in the Bukit Panjang electoral division of the Legislative Assembly. Up to date two miles of road have already been completed and 14 miles are under construction and are expected to be completed by the end of the year.

STUDY OF CHINESE IN ENGLISH SCHOOLS


    3. Mr Goh Tong Liang asked the Minister for Education since when has Chinese been taught as a second language in English schools; whether he is satisfied with the progress made, and

Column: 788

what steps he has taken or proposes to take to make the pupils interested in its study.

    Mr Chew Swee Kee: Mr Speaker, Sir, Chinese has been taught as a second language in some English schools as far back as 1951 and earlier. At the beginning of 1957, however, vernacular languages became a compulsory part of the curricula in English schools, although it was not always possible then to get enough vernacular teachers. However, Chinese is not affected in this respect and the Ministry has an adequate number of Chinese teachers in English schools.

    In the Primary schools good progress is being made, though naturally some pupils are not very diligent.

    Many of the Chinese teachers in English schools have been trained and others are undergoing training. This is tending to make the pupils more interested in the study of Chinese. Furthermore, vernacular language marks count towards a pupil's position in class and this gives an incentive to study.

    In the Secondary schools in Forms II and III good progress is being made. In Forms IV and V a fair number of pupils are making good progress but some have no grounding in Chinese and found the subject very difficult when it was made compulsory. In some of these cases pupils in this category were therefore allowed to drop the study of Chinese.

MINISTRY OF HEALTH AND
UNIONS OF MEDICAL AND
HEALTH DEPARTMENT

    4. Mr Lee Choon Eng asked the Minister for Health if he will make a statement on the progress of the negotiations between the Ministry of Health and the Unions of the Medical and Health Department on the claims for revision of salaries and conditions of service submitted by the Unions since 1956.

    Mr E. B. David: With your permission, Sir, I will reply to this question since the matter is within my portfolio.

    At the time when Staff Unions of the Medical Department submitted salary claims in 1956, there were a number of

Column: 789

claims in other departments also to be dealt with. It was therefore agreed with the Staff Side of the Civil Service Joint Council that all these claims would receive consideration in an agreed order of priority. In accordance with this agreement, the medical unions' claims came up for examination last year. A complete survey of all the posts in the various services affected was undertaken late last year. Following this survey the Government placed before the unions in March this year the broad outlines of its proposals and since then there have been a number of meetings and discussions. In the case of certain groups of officers, only a few matters of detail remain unsolved, whereas in other cases it is clear that an agreed settlement can only be reached after further discussion.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Can the Chief Secretary tell us when he can expect to have all these claims settled, because it has been too long a delay since 1956?

    Mr David: I have every hope, Sir, that these claims will be finally settled before the end of this year, but I must point Out that in negotiations there are two sides to the proceedings and the blame cannot be laid entirely at the door of one side.

GOVERNMENT TRANSPORT POLICY
(Statement by the Minister for Communications and Works)


10.11 a.m.

    Mr Francis Thomas: I have to make a statement on transport policy, Sir, and I must, with regret, inform this House that I have not been able, after very full study, consultation and discussion, to find any way of rationalising Singapore's bus system without heavy cost to public funds, involving at least some millions of dollars. The House is also aware that the funds available for this sort of purpose are limited at any time, and especially limited in the trading and economic conditions of 1958. We have not got the necessary cash. The result is that I am not able now to go forward

Column: 790

with the Government's policy of rationalisation and unification as a basis of later full nationalisation. The effect of this will be that we shall have for the time being to make the best we can of the existing bus system, with all its defects. This will not be easy but it must be tried.

    During the past three and a half years we have in my Ministry covered a great deal of the preliminary work on which future action for unification will depend. We are now considering what amendments must be made to match the Omnibus Services Licensing Authority to changed circumstances. Probably the Omnibus Services Licensing Authority, somewhat adapted in form, will have to be used as the main instrument of policy pending provision of the necessary money for unification.

    I propose seeking a new transport adviser to join my Ministry for two years under the Colonial Development and Welfare Plan. He will assist us in the day-to-day decisions necessary during the interim period prior to unification. He will also continue the preliminary work needed as the basis for unification.

     Hon. Members will be disappointed that execution of our policy has to be deferred. I am sorry about that. They will, however, remember, I hope, that it is only deferred. The essential obstacle is lack of money. When money can be found, I do not foresee any other insoluble difficulty.

    I have tried to keep this statement as short as possible, Mr Speaker, so that hon. Members can fix their minds on the main problem of finance without being confused by a mass of detail or by a long history of all the different work done and action taken during the past three and a half years. Hon. Members may, however, want clarification or more details on certain points. If they will say what clarification they want, I will do my best, with your permission, Sir, to satisfy them.

PRESERVATION OF PUBLIC SECURITY (AMENDMENT) BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

10.23 a.m.

    The Chief Minister (Tun Lim Yew Hock): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

Column: 793



    In Sessional Paper Cmd. 33 of 1957 the House was made aware of the Communist threat to Singapore and the tactics employed by Communist Front supporters in their efforts ultimately to establish a dictatorial Communist state. Since the Command Paper was published, there have been continuing attempts by supporters of Communism to undermine the authority of the Government and it has been necessary to detain a number of subversive elements who had succeeded in establishing themselves in positions of authority in respectable democratic institutions.

    In August 1957 subversive elements succeeded in gaining control of the Central Executive Committee of the People's Action Party and were actively engaged in promoting the interests of the Communist Front amongst students and trade unions. Had these activities been allowed to continue unchecked, there is little doubt that they would shortly have presented a grave threat to the security of Singapore. The Government accordingly decided to take action under the Preservation of Public Security Ordinance against these evil forces. The justification for such action was amply proved when out of 20 P.A.P. leaders arrested, two confessed to being Communists, five were identified as members of the Communist under around organisation, and the Appeal Tribunal confirmed the detention orders made in every single case. At the same time, it was considered necessary to arrest and detain 15 so-called trade union leaders who were known Communist Front workers. In their cases also the Appeal Tribunal confirmed the detention orders. From statements made by those detained and from documents seized at the time of their arrest, there was ample evidence to show the intentions of these people to penetrate legal, democratic organisations in Singapore and, after assuming control, to exploit their legal aims in the furtherance of Communist policies.

    While some Communist extremists were concentrating their attention on political parties and trade unions, others were directing their efforts to the subversion

Column: 794

of students. It was known that a number of student members of the Communist Front were responsible for organising student picnics and social gatherings for the purpose of indoctrinating those who attended with Communist ideologies. At the end of September 1957, following the arrest of the ringleaders of this campaign, 19 detention orders were made and confirmed. Documents recovered during Police operations against these students proved the Communist sympathies of those arrested.

    Early in 1958 Communist sympathisers turned their attention to a campaign designed to inculcate in the population feelings of hatred and dissatisfaction towards democratic government and the existing social order. So-called "cultural companies" published or distributed booklets criticising the Governments of Singapore and the Federation of Malaya and praising the Communist terrorists in the Federation as patriots and fighters for their motherland, Malaya. In an operation in March 1958, the Police raided 8 premises and recovered over 2,000 of these undesirable booklets. Evidence was obtained which showed that these "cultural companies" were distributing the undesirable publications in the Federation and in Sarawak and further evidence proved the association of one of the companies with Malayan Communist Party members in Johore.

    By May 1958 information was available to the Police that Communist "power groups" still exist in Singapore and are made up of highly indoctrinated and experienced Communist personnel. The duty of these power groups is to use their influence in specific operations such as election campaigns or the capture of control of trade unions or political parties. Information has been received that extremist control of the P.A.P. Central Executive Committee was achieved in precisely this manner in August last year. In June this year, Sir, members of this "power group" were arrested and 8 detention orders have been made and confirmed. Two of these detainees have disclosed that they were under instructions to penetrate

Column: 795

the P.A.P. and trade unions and organise Communist activities in these legal bodies.

    Sir, the detentions which have been made and confirmed by the Appeal Tribunal since the second half of 1956 provide a clear indication of the ceaseless vigilance which is necessary to thwart the activities of a small but entirely unprincipled section of the community which seeks to overthrow parliamentary democracy, and impose upon the great mass of law-abiding citizens a totalitarian system of government.

    No freedom-loving people will lightly approve legislation which permits of detention without trial. It must however be borne in mind, Sir, that a great part of the information which leads to action against the Communist and their fellow-travellers is gathered from erstwhile accomplices or comrades, or from persons whose lives would be in jeopardy if the fact of their providing such information were known to the Communists, and for this reason, Sir, such evidence cannot be published in open court.

    In the light of the events of the past three years and the strong evidence that powerful influences are still at work with the intention of overthrowing the present form of democratic Government in Singapore, it is the clear duty of the Government to retain the extraordinary powers given to it under the Preservation of Public Security Ordinance in order to protect the security of the citizens of Singapore. The new Constitution which is to come into force next year is a rich prize indeed and we must do everything in our power to see that the Communists do not capture this prize.

    Sir, the Government asks for the extension of the Preservation of Public Security Ordinance for one year only and the power to extend current detention orders by one year only, in order that the next Government, the first Government of the new State of Singapore, may be elected and take up office in propitious conditions and may have a few months to make up its mind on whether or not there is a need for further

Column: 796

legislation to give it extraordinary powers of arrest and detention to deal with the dangers to security against which, in present circumstances, the ordinary processes of law are inadequate defence.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Question proposed.

10.31 a.m.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng (Queenstown): Mr Speaker, Sir, this new amending Bill to the original Ordinance has come as a big surprise to the people of Singapore.

    Clause 2 of this Bill seeks to extend the period of the Ordinance from three to four years. I cannot see the necessity for extending the period of that Ordinance.

    The Chief Minister just now quoted the activities of the P.A.P. leaders and the students. All these P.A.P. leaders and the students who were considered subversive at that time are now under detention; some of them have been banished. So I cannot see any reason why the life of this Bill should be extended.

    When the Ordinance was first introduced, the then Chief Minister who was the architect of this Bill, had this to say. I quote from column 702 of the Hansard dated 21st September, 1955:

    "Sir, there have been some criticisms - on the face of them legitimate, and some of them, in fact, very constructive - directed against this Bill. The first one I will deal with is that it seeks to make law for three years what has so far been law for only three months at a time. In the past we had to renew this law every three months. The question of renewal of a law every three months was based on the concept of the existence of an emergency."

He went on to say:

    "This Government has never avoided, and so long as I survive" -

unfortunately, he never survived his term of office -

    "on this side will never avoid its responsibilities. and instead of making it four years and 'passing the buck' to the next government, we will have to face this House, at least five months before its dissolution...".

Sir, as I said, unfortunately, the then Chief Minister did not survive his term

Column: 797

of office or else he may now have to swallow his own words. He has clearly stated, Sir, that he did not intend to make this Ordinance a permanent one. If that is so, why then extend the period from three to four years? If it is not going to be permanent, it should not be extended. By extending the period for one more year, there is the likelihood that it may again have to come to this House for a further extension. After one year and another, it may then become permanent. Is this the policy of the Government, Sir, and if that is so, is it the intention of the Government to tie the hands of the next Government which may come into power?

    This Ordinance, originally introduced and approved, came into operation on 21st October, 1955, which means that it will expire on 21st October this year. With this amending Bill, Sir, the period will then be extended to 21st October, 1959. Sir, let us look at it this way. How long is the life of this Assembly? When will this Assembly be dissolved and when is the next election to be held? According to the Chief Minister, he said that he will have the election by March next year. Then if the election is to be held by March next year and the life of this Assembly is up to March next year, why extend the life of this Ordinance further than March, 1959? I think the Government is trying to pass the buck to the next Government, according to what the then Chief Minister who framed this Ordinance said.

    New clause 3 of the Bill, Sir, seeks power to be given to the Chief Secretary if the Governor in Council is satisfied to extend the period of detention for two years to a further period not exceeding 12 months at a time. Again, Sir, when the Ordinance was passed, it was on the very clear understanding that the period of detention would only be for two years and no more. Why this sudden change of attitude, Sir, on the part of the Government? Is it to prevent our colleague the Member for Bukit Timah (Mr Lim Ching Siong) from contesting the next election? Is that the intention of the Government so that he may be further

Column: 798

detained while the Assembly dissolves and we contest the next election? If so, let the Chief Minister say so.

    Sir, this Bill has caused a lot of misery to the people of Singapore.

    An hon. Member: Ha, ha!

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Oh yes, certainly quite a lot. It has resulted in my tabling a motion on 21st April this year on the torture of detainees. The Hon, the Chief Secretary is holding his head because he denied at that time that there was torture by the Police. Whether that is true or not, I leave it to the public to decide, it has been debated and I am not prepared to debate it further. If any Member would like me to refresh his memory, I would refer him to columns 263 to 270 of the Hansard (Vol. 3). There he will find reference to the torture. Apart from this alleged torture, I have on the Order Paper another motion in my name. This is again as a result of the Preservation of Public Security Ordinance. This time it is not about torture, it is about banishment and I will come to that later.

    The Chief Minister: On a point of order. Is the hon. Member anticipating a debate on his motion?

    Mr Speaker: I was watching that very carefully and I do not think he has gone as far as that.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: I am much obliged to you, Mr Speaker, Sir, because I said that I would come to that later and not now.

    Sir, under the Preservation of Public Security Ordinance, detainees born, bred and educated in Malaya were deported to China. Now I cannot understand the policy of the Government. When these detainees were arrested, they were arrested under this Ordinance and not on a banishment order.

    Mr Speaker: Order. Is the hon. Member now touching on his motion? If he is, he is out of order.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: I am sorry, Sir. I was just trying to state what harm this new Bill will do to the people of Singapore. I would therefore appeal to the Members of this House not to accept

Column: 799

this Bill. As I have said, it is a question of whether the people of Singapore will accept this Bill. With all the experience of alleged torture - I call it "alleged" instead of "actual" because the Chief Minister denied it - and of banishment, I am sure that the people of Singapore do not want this Bill at all. I am against the Bill.

10.40 a.m.

    Mr A. R. Lazarous (Farrer Park): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise to protest against this Bill. The Chief Minister has just given a catalogue of reasons why he thinks such an undemocratic measure is so necessary for the democracy of Singapore.

    Sir, I must say that since last year, many people have been arrested and detained, and no valid reasons were given to this Assembly or in public why a few people have been released and many of them are still in detention camps. One example I have in mind is the recent release of Dr Chuang. He was released immediately after the defeat of the Labour Front in the Kallang by-election. One would have thought that probably he was detained because he was plotting against the Labour Front election.

    Sir, the Chief Minister is not the first politician who, in the name of democracy, seeks to destroy democracy by jailing his political opponents. There were men before him and there might be men after him to follow his procedure. When I look at the vacant seat of the Member for Bukit Timah which was caused through the operation of this Ordinance, I feel like asking this House to observe two minutes' silence in honour of that Assemblyman.

    Mr Francis Thomas: Silence by you in the House!

    Mr Lazarous: Yes. The Member for Bukit Timah who continues to represent his constituency in that national assembly which is popularly known as Changi Jail.

    Sir, from a brief study of Asian history, I am convinced that many of the Asian leaders emerged from British political prisons and I know that the men who sit in Changi Jail will soon grace the seat of power, and when they do

Column: 800

come to power and the same Ordinance is in force, how many of us who sit in this Assembly will conduct our debates in Changi Jail is a matter for conjecture. Sir, 1 said once that a man who holds the gun will say the other man is a subversive. So we will know, when these people who are in Changi Jail are released, what the result will be for all the people who are supporting this Bill. I do not, if possible, want to go to Changi Jail and this is the reason why I oppose this Bill.

10.44 a.m.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew (Tanjong Pagar): Mr Speaker, Sir, I should have thought that as there are seven Liberal-Socialist speakers as against three P.A.P., they would have given me the courtesy of speaking later on in the debate, but they are just moral cowards.

    Mr Speaker: Order. The hon. Member knows that that expression is unparliamentary and he must withdraw it.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Very well, Sir. Nevertheless, I cannot help feeling -

    Mr Speaker: Has the hon. Member withdrawn the expression?

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: I have withdrawn it, Sir.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, we meet to discuss the Preservation of Public Security Ordinance in circumstances and conditions which are quite different from what they were three years ago, but the speeches by the two illustrious Members on the Opposition side, serve to remind us how little one can learn in three years. I was sorry to hear the Hon, the Chief Minister read his recital of subversive activities since the Bill was passed three years ago. It did not carry that ring of conviction of someone who had been intimately associated with the problem. It sounded like a recital having been composed and prepared by someone else. We, Sir, in the People's Action Party compose and prepare our own symphony, and I came to this House today with a statement on (1) what we intend to debate, which is important, and (2) what some people might want to know about what we intend to do next year.

Column: 801



    We welcome the form in which the extension to the Preservation of Public Security Ordinance is being sought, as an amending Bill to extend it from three to four years - one extra year to cover the extended life of the Labour Front Coalition Government until it dies with this Assembly in April next year.

    It makes it easier and simpler for us to state our position clearly and succinctly. Three and a half years ago, the People's Action Party fought and won three out of the four seats it contested. One of its promises was to oppose the Emergency Regulations. Six months after that, the former leader of the Government, one David Saul Marshall, tried a sleight of hand in this Assembly. As he brought in the Preservation of Public Security Ordinance with his right, he gallantly struck out the Emergency Regulations with his left.
